coredata.dc:title: Two-dimensional fluids in a periodic external potential: Intercalation in graphite
coredata.dc:creator: Karim, Omar A.
Pettitt, B.Montgomery
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
An inhomogeneous anisotropic integral equation theory is used to predict the sixfold pattern of intensity in the structure factor for graphite intercalation compounds. The competition of length scales implied by particle size and the underlying lattice through the interplay of the liquid packing structure with the graphitic external field is shown to be responsible for the observed halo-like features in S(k). By using a density functional motivated ansatz no explicit truncation of the angular Fourier components of the density distributions was necessary.

Montgomery PETTITT Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, USA Received 18 February 1987 An inhomogeneous anisotropic integral equation theory is used to predict the sixfold pattern of intensity in the structure factor for graphite intercalation compounds. The competition of length scales implied by particle size and the underlying lattice through the interplay of the liquid packing structure with the graphitic external field is shown to be responsible for the observed halo-like features in S(k). By using a density functional motivated ansatz no explicit truncation of the angular Fourier components of the density distributions was necessary. 1. Introduction The study of two-dimensional condensed phase systems has attracted a good deal of recent attention [1,2]. Experimental advances in structural determination by X-ray scattering including those utilizing synchrotron sources have revealed a variety of interesting phenomena [ 3 ]. Much theoretical work has been aimed at describing the properties of two-dimensional interfaces [4] and phase transitions of two-dimensional systems [ 5 ]. Many such systems of interest may be physically characterized as two-dimensional fluids in the presence of an external field. In particular, Langmuir surface films may be characterized as two-dimensional polar films in the presence of a non-periodic external field. The physical properties of adsorbed monolayers on crystal surfaces is a case where the external field is periodic and the two-dimensional overlayer may be anisotropic. In this work a system with a similar mathematical characterization is studied, namely the intercalation of alkali atoms in between the planes of graphite. This system has been characterized experimentally for rubidium atoms [6] using X- ray diffraction techniques. The alkali atoms may be taken to be ionized and to be screened by the excess charge in the graphite lattice [1,7]. Thus the alkali-alkali effective pair potential chosen for this work takes the form of that for a one-com- ponent plasma. This system is of theoretical interest due to the fact that an exact solution for the properties of a two-dimensional one-component plasma at a reduced coupling of 2 exists [ 8 ]. However, for this work we have explored a lower, and physically more interesting temperature range within the hypemetted chain approx- imation for the liquid structure. For one-dimensional cases with physically interesting coupling parameters integro-differential equations have provided a detailed view of the structure and thermodynamics of liquids in an external field [9,10]. The present treatment provides an analysis and the associated numerical results for a two-dimensional sys- tem subject to a periodic external field. Density waves in this system are induced by the periodic lattice. In the present contribution the first YBG equation couples the pair correlations to the singlet density profile. In section 2 we outline the theoretical method to be used and note the approximations which make the cal- culation tractable. Section 3 contains the results of the calculations using a model for the intercalation of Rb atoms in graphite and a discussion of the implications of the results. 72 0 009-2614/87/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. In this work we report the results of an approximate theory that appears to capture the qualitative aspects of the experimental data on two-dimensional alkali fluids intercalated in between the layers of graphite with a significant reduction in computational overhead. The initial direct correlation function, c(r), is taken from an HNC calculation for an isotropic, two-dimensional fluid with the pair potential given by (3). An iterative solution using this c(r) is then obtained for p(r) using eq. (7) and the one-body potential from eq. (2). A pair distribution function for the system in the presence of the anisotropic (hex- agonal) lattice field may then be calculated from eq. (8). This solution is not completely self consistent in that the non-trivial singlet distribution function has not been resubstituted into the Omstein-Zernike equation. However, the final c(r) implied by using eqs. (7) and (8) does contain substantial anisotropic character. In section 3 the results of a calculation using this procedure are presented for a system whose parameters were chosen to describe the intercalation of rubidium ions in between the layers of graphite. 3. Results and discussion For this demonstration we have chosen a bulk surface density ofRb ions p = 0.02926 ions/A2 at a temperature of 300 K. The implied screening at this state dictates that K in eq. (3) is 0.49 A-1. The strength, K, of the periodic potential was taken from the work of Moss and co-workers and is 0.45 in reduced units. The equations were initiated with p being the constant bulk density. The OZ equation (eq. (4)) was then solved with the HNC closure (eq. (5)). Then the solution to eq. (7) was obtained by guessing/? being constant and iterating until self-consistency in p( r) was reached. The converged p( r) was then used in eq. (8) to produce the final anisotropic pair distribution function. The two-dimensional Fourier transforms were performed with the aid of the fast Fourier transform routines of the IMSL package. This also was the method of choice for calculating the angular dependence o{S(k). The lattice orientation implied by eq. (3) yields an anisotropy for the distribution functions viewed along the x axis versus those observed along the y axis. In fig. 1 we compare the results for the singlet density dis- tribution as viewed along the x and y axes. Notice that not only do the different cuts reflect the different peri- odicities sampled, but the population in the saddle region between two near-neighbor lattice sites is also evident in the y direction. This latter result has been observed in a different context previously [ 14]. In a completely self-consistent calculation one might expect even more sharply peaked singlet and pair distributions due to the reinforcement of the distribution functions through the hierarchical equations. Fig. 2 displays cuts through the pair distribution function also along the x and y axes. Not surprisingly we find a competition between the length scales dictated by the size of the particles and the shape of the underlying lattice. At small distances the pair correlations are dominated by particle shape and size as would be expected by consideration of just the first few terms in a Mayer-like cluster expansion [15]. Long-ranged correlations among particles induced by the lattice are clearly present for large r. These correlations do not die off after two or three diameters as in the case of simple fluids or liquids composed of a neutral molecules away from a critical state. Fluids structured by such a periodic external potential thus have a qualitatively different behav- ior in the observable X-ray [6] or neutron [16] diffraction patterns as compared to their isotropic counterparts. This is a clear consequence of the alkali atoms being somewhat localized at the center of the graphite hexagons. Several of the more typical liquid structure features of S(k) are also found in the data displayed in fig. 3. The structure factor is found to start at a low value at k^=ky=0 and to rise to a simple first peak (ring in 2D) with only a weak anisotropy apparent. Some remnants of a simple fluid structure are evident at larger | * | values but are quickly damped. The placement and size of the halo features is in good quantitative agreement with experiment [2,6]. 4. Conclusion In summary, we have described a relatively simple low-order theory for the intensity and symmetry patterns revealed in the diffraction data [6] for intercalated alkali fluids in between the layers of graphite. The intense peaks in S(k) with sixfold symmetry are due to the partial localization of density in the sixfold symmetric wells of the lattice field. Our analysis indicated that the halo feature around the intense reflections in S(k) are due to the interplay of the liquid packing structure with that dictated by the external field. The approximation of using an isotropic liquid state c(r) in the self-consistent p(r) calculation is similar in spirit to the mean field density functional theories of freezing by Ramakrishnan and Yussouff [12] as well as Oxtoby and Haymet [13]. Such freezing theories have been successful at reproducing many of the thermo- dynamic properties of the liquid-solid transition. Those results may have some bearing on the success of the approximation used in the current theory of intercalation diffraction patterns. Work along the lines of a com- putationally tractable and internally (self-) consistent theory for two-dimensional liquids in the presence of a periodic external field is currently in progress [11].
